content.html_value:
Physics and the Universe

The science of Physics goes beyond the limits of planet Earth and, through its studies, provides us with essential information about our universe.

Like any science, Physics is also directly connected to the language of mathematics. For this reason, we begin this section with Chapter 6 of the First Steps part, which is dedicated to the study of mathematics in connection with other sciences. Thus, we recommend reading the first five chapters of that section before continuing (History Tracers Editors. First Steps).

Although in school we are introduced to subjects called Science or Physics before entering university, teaching often limits itself to presenting only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be referred to as proto-Physics or pre-Physics, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (González Redondo, Francisco A., ; González Redondo, Francisco A., ; History Tracers Team, The knowledge). In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Physics and proto-Physics, gradually connecting them to Physics through mathematics.
Chapter 1: The Origin of What We Observe

value.name: Shared Origin
value.desc: In this text, we take a journey back in time to understand what current measurements reveal about the universe’s past.

value.name: Simplicity vs. Complexity
value.desc: Despite more than 13.8 billion years of evolution of the universe, we often still wish to be like it was in its beginnings. Why?

value.name: Two sides
value.desc: good vs. evil, left vs. right, matter vs. energy, up vs. down. Is this duality enough?

value.name: Expanding...
value.desc: Continuing from the previous text, we see that dividing into just two sides ends up doing omissions

value.name: Always present
value.desc: many times we are so focused on ourselves or on opposites that we do not notice what is always present.
